title: NHS staff were rehired in three years and given new jobs after £92m payoffs
title_page: NHS staff were rehired in three years and given new jobs after £92m payoffs | Daily Mail Online
text:
Thousands of NHS staff were laid off after being handed generous redundancy pay offs only to re-employed by the health service a short time later.
A reorganisation of the NHS masterminded by the former health secretary Andrew Lansley was branded a ‘merry-go-round of waste’ last night.
Mr Lansley abolished 161 NHS bodies and created new ones to give doctors more freedom.
Thousands of NHS staff who were given generous redundancy payoffs were rehired within three years
As a result, 2,641 staff were laid off and rehired in the three years from April 2012 and average pay-offs topping £36,000, Parliamentary questions by Labour have revealed.
In total these staff received £92million in redundancy in that period.
Shadow health secretary Heidi Alexander told The Times: ‘If you wanted a symbol of the folly of the NHS reorganisation, then firing and rehiring managers must surely be it. On David Cameron’s watch it’s been payoffs for managers and pay cuts for nurses.
‘This merry-go-round of waste is unacceptable particularly at a time when the NHS needs every penny it can get,’ he said.
The newspaper revealed that one married couple received redundancy totalling almost £1million but moved to new posts in the same hospital a few months later.
On David Cameron’s watch the NHS has seen large payoffs for managers and pay cuts for nurses
Labour’s questions also found that national bodies created or given new powers by the reforms spent £159million on management consultancy.
NHS England, which allocates most health funding, had the biggest consultancy bill of £101million.
This was followed by the financial regulator Monitor which paid £47million.
Ms Alexander said: ‘Patients left waiting hours on end in A&E this winter will be rightly furious at these figures.’
A Department of Health spokesperson said: ‘We have introduced tough new rules so that any salaries above the PM’s now have to be scrutinised by the Department and we’re both capping payouts and clawing back redundancy payments when highly-paid staff return to the same part of the public sector within a year.
